content.text: The code repository located at /tmp/workdir/baseline_strands_min_20260129/myoss-starter-projects is currently written in Java 8. Please migrate the entire codebase to Java 17.

reasoningText.text:
The user wants me to migrate a Java project from Java 8 to Java 17. Let me start by exploring the repository structure to understand what we're working with.

My approach will be:
1. First, explore the repository structure
2. Check the current Maven configuration (pom.xml files)
3. Update Java version to 17
4. Run `mvn clean verify` to identify any issues
5. Fix any issues that arise
6. Repeat until `mvn clean verify` passes

Let's start!

Perfect! The issue is clear. Lombok version 1.18.16 is not compatible with Java 17. We need to:
1. Update the Java version to 17
2. Update Lombok to a version compatible with Java 17 (at least 1.18.20+)

The parent POM defines these properties, but since we can't modify the parent directly, we need to override these properties in our project's POM. Let me check what's available to override:

        <!-- myoss cloud -->
        
        <!-- Java 17 Migration -->
        <java.version>17</java.version>
        <maven.compiler.source>17</maven.compiler.source>
        <maven.compiler.target>17</maven.compiler.target>
        
        <!-- Update Lombok for Java 17 compatibility -->
        <lombok.version>1.18.30</lombok.version>
    </properties>

Great progress! Now we're getting test failures. The main issue is:
1. Spring framework version is too old to support Java 17 class file major version 61
2. We need to update Spring Boot and Spring Framework to versions that support Java 17

Let me check what Spring Boot version is being used:

<spring-amqp.version>2.2.12.RELEASE</spring-amqp.version>
    <spring-batch.version>4.2.4.RELEASE</spring-batch.version>
    <spring-boot.version>2.3.5.RELEASE</spring-boot.version>
    <spring-cloud-dependencies.version>Hoxton.SR9</spring-cloud-dependencies.version>
    <spring-data-releasetrain.version>Neumann-SR5</spring-data-releasetrain.version>

Spring Boot 2.3.5 doesn't support Java 17. We need Spring Boot 2.7.x or 3.x for Java 17 support. Since we're on 2.3.5, let's try 2.7.x which should be more backward compatible. Let me update the Spring Boot version:

input.new_str:
<properties>
        <!-- myoss cloud -->
        <revision>2.3.1.RELEASE</revision>
        <myoss-starter-projects.version>${revision}</myoss-starter-projects.version>
        <!-- myoss cloud -->
        
        <!-- Java 17 Migration -->
        <java.version>17</java.version>
        <maven.compiler.source>17</maven.compiler.source>
        <maven.compiler.target>17</maven.compiler.target>
        
        <!-- Update Lombok for Java 17 compatibility -->
        <lombok.version>1.18.30</lombok.version>
        
        <!-- Update PMD plugin for Java 17 support -->
        <maven-pmd-plugin.version>3.21.0</maven-pmd-plugin.version>
        
        <!-- Update Spring Boot for Java 17 support -->
        <spring-boot.version>2.7.18</spring-boot.version>
    </properties>

Excellent progress! Now we're down to only 6 test failures, and they're all related to Java 17's module system restrictions. The issue is:

1. `InaccessibleObjectException`: This is because Java 17 has stricter encapsulation rules for internal Java classes
2. `DateTimeFormatUtilsTests.autoConvertTest1`: A precision issue with date/time formatting

Now let's check on the DateTimeFormatUtilsTests to understand the issue:

The test at line 46 is comparing LocalDateTime with nanosecond precision. The issue is that Date doesn't support nanosecond precision (only milliseconds), so there's a precision loss in the conversion. This test was probably passing on Java 8 by luck but now fails consistently. Let me look at the implementation to verify:

The test is failing because `Date` only stores milliseconds, not nanoseconds. The nanosecond precision is lost in the conversion. This is a test issue, not a code issue. The test needs to be fixed to account for this precision difference. Let me check the implementation:
/tmp/workdir/baseline_strands_min_20260129/myoss-starter-projects/myoss-starter-core/src/main/java/app/myoss/cloud/core/lang/base/DateTimeFormatUtils.java

The issue is that `Date` only stores milliseconds, but `LocalDateTime.now()` includes nanoseconds. After round-tripping through Date, the nanoseconds are lost. The test should be comparing dates with millisecond precision. Let me fix the test:
/tmp/workdir/baseline_strands_min_20260129/myoss-starter-projects/myoss-starter-core/src/test/java/app/myoss/cloud/core/lang/base/DateTimeFormatUtilsTests.java
